boat.name: Dunlin

owners.note: Reported in 1999 (Antiqua Classic Yacht Regatta), that she only had three owners since 1890. OGA member, Roger G Ward, advertised 'Dunlin' for sale in Gaffers Logs, 1977/2, 1979/1 and 1980/1.

boat.full_description:
62-year-old Philip Kerin, a British citizen based in the Caribbean, was rescued on 12 September 2004 whilst sailing from Antigua to Falmouth. His stricken 19th century yacht, 'Dunlin', was nearly 350 miles out in the Atlantic. Coastguards received a satellite signal from an emergency beacon 345 miles south-west of the Isles of Scilly. A Nimrod reconnaissance aircraft from RAF Kinloss, Scotland, was scrambled. The MV Sydney Express responded to an emergency call sent out by the coastguards, and picked up Mr. Kerin.

The 'Dunlin' had been well known in classic yacht circles as a regular at events in Antigua. The 28' Camper and Nicholson sailed all three races in 1999 despite breaking off the end of her bowsprit in the first race. Built in 1890 as a Falmouth Quay Punt she was the oldest boat present.

Read the skipper's account of the rescue.
boat.construction_details: Pitch pine on oak/teak, lead keel
boat.short_description: After two years renovation 1975 - 1977 she was sold by R.G Ward. Lost, mid-Atlantic, 12 September 2004, with owner since 1979, Phil Nerin, being rescued.
